text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 5.21.7.3(1): Added Rev. Proc. 2017-15 to discuss Qualiﬁed Intermediary
5.21.7.4.1(6): Added reference to the MCAR Database and relocated this subsection to IRM Renumbered subsequent subsections.
IRM 5.21.7.4.1(11)(c): Note clariﬁed procedures when MCAR coordinator should report an update to United States Competent Authority.
5.21.7.4.3: Relocated this section from IRM 5.21.7.4.11 and clariﬁed procedures for processing for inbound MCAR cases.
IRM 5.21.7.4.4(1): Added reference to check IDRS for inbound MCAR cases.
IRM 5.21.7.4.8(2): Added explanation relating to dual citizenship.
IRM 5.21.7.4.8(11): Added reference to MCAR database.
Editorial changes have been made throughout this

IRM 5.21.7 supersedes IRM 5.21.7, dated 11/13/2015. This IRM also incorporates Interim Guidance SBSE 05-0318-009, Guidance for Withdrawing an Outbound Mutual Collection Assistance Request Case Referral.
Revenue officers in SB/SE Field Collection (FC)

) Purpose: This IRM provides instructions and guidelines for working cases which have unusual international aspects that must be considered. The Scope and dures are written for international revenue officers but also apply to domestic revenue officers. Employees in SB/SE and employees in other functions also refer to these procedures. (
) Audience: Revenue officers in Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) in Collection. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy, SBSE. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy, SBSE, Global Strategic Compliance (GSC). (
) Primary Stakeholder: SB/SE Collection and Large Business and (LB&I). (
) Primary Goals: This IRM provides the fundamental knowledge and guidance for working International cases (
) This IRM section provides guidelines and procedures for working cases that require special handling. (

Field Collection territory managers and group managers are responsible for ensuring compliance with the guidance and procedures described in this IRM.
Director, Field Collection Report
This monthly report encompasses all Field Collection including International and provides measures on the performance of Field Collection. International Territory Report
This monthly report provides measures on the performance of the International Territory.

International program reviews are conducted on an ad hoc basis to verify compliance with IRM procedures and to address ﬁndings by the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration/U.S. Government countability Office. Operational reviews are conducted by the territory manager and area director annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to ad
ministrative and compliance requirements.

) The U.S. Competent Authority (USCA) coordinates tax cases involving country or a U.S. territory. A taxpayer can request the USCA assistance in cases involving treaty beneﬁts claimed by the taxpayer and resolve cases double taxation. See IRM
, Mutual Agreement Procedures and Guidelines. (

) The Commissioner, LB&I, is the USCA and is charged with administering provisions of tax treaties, interpreting and applying the tax treaties, and reaching mutual agreement in speciﬁc cases. The USCA conducts the competent authority process through two offices, the Advance Pricing and Internal Revenue Manual

The following publications are used for International Issues. They can be used as technical reference material or provided to taxpayer. These publications are available for reference on SERP and on the internet at http://www.irs.gov.
5.21 International and Insular Issues

Mutual Agreement Program (APMA) and the Treaty Assistance and tion Team (TAIT). APMA has primary responsibility for cases arising under business proﬁts and associated enterprises articles of U.S. tax treaties. TAIT has primary responsibility for cases arising under all other articles of U.S. treaties. TAIT also has primary responsibility for cases arising under U.S. treaties with respect to estate and gift taxes. APMA and TAIT each can consider cases arising under the permanent establishment articles of U.S. treaties, and both offices will coordinate and collaborate on such cases, and any other cases, as appropriate. (
) Rev. Proc.
contains the procedures that allow a U.S. taxpayer to request assistance from the USCA on issues arising under a tax treaty between the United States and a foreign country. Rev. Proc.
procedures for requesting assistance from the USCA under the provisions of tax coordination agreement between the United States and a U.S. Territory. (
) As per Rev. Proc.
and Rev. Proc.

“the IRS will suspend further administrative action, including assessment and collection with respect to the issues under Competent Authority consideration unless until USCA instructs otherwise. ”Standard administrative procedures will continue to apply to issues over which the USCA has not assumed (
) Sometimes the cases being worked by the USCA are also assigned to a Revenue Officer (RO) ineither status
or status
Contact and with the USCA prior to initiating collection actions in such cases to avoid violating the suspension guidelines in Rev. Proc.
and Rev. Proc.
Commencing collection action without prior coordination with the USCA could be counter-productive to the Service’s interest or unfair to the See Rev. Proc.

) The USCA analyst working the case will identify Field status via IDRS. The USCA analyst will send an encrypted e-mail to the SB/SE Collection Policy (CP), Global Strategic Compliance analyst who acts as the insular area (
) The USCA e-mail will be worded as follows: COMPETENT AUTHORITY NOTE: Tax years ____ and ____ are currently under the jurisdiction of the USCA(SE:LB&I:IN). Pursuant to Rev. Proc.
, [or Proc.

, if applicable] the IRS will suspend further administrative action respect to the issues under Competent Authority consideration, including assess- ment and collection procedures. Therefore, until negotiations are complete with other taxing jurisdiction’s Competent Authority, the RO should contact the U.S. Competent Authority to discuss any contemplated collection action for these before proceeding with collection action. The U.S. Competent Authority analyst this case is ______________ and can be reached at _____________. Please contact with this analyst as soon as possible to discuss any proposed actions on the case. You will be notiﬁed when the case is completed and Competent jurisdiction relinquished. (

) The CP analyst will copy the USCA analyst’s e-mail message and paste it the ICS history. It will be the obligation of the USCA analyst to notify the CP analyst when the case is closed. The CP analyst will make a note about the

Mutual Agreement Program (APMA) and the Treaty Assistance and Interpreta- tion Team (TAIT). APMA has primary responsibility for cases arising under the business proﬁts and associated enterprises articles of U.S. tax treaties. TAIT has primary responsibility for cases arising under all other articles of U.S. tax treaties. TAIT also has primary responsibility for cases arising under U.S. tax treaties with respect to estate and gift taxes. APMA and TAIT each can consider cases arising under the permanent establishment articles of U.S. tax

jurisdiction of the USCA(SE:LB&I:IN). Pursuant to Rev. Proc. 2015-40, [or Rev. 2006-23, if applicable] the IRS will suspend further administrative action with to the issues under Competent Authority consideration, including assess- and collection procedures. Therefore, until negotiations are complete with the taxing jurisdiction’s Competent Authority, the RO should contact the U.S. Authority to discuss any contemplated collection action for these years proceeding with collection action. The U.S. Competent Authority analyst on case is ______________ and can be reached at _____________. Please with this analyst as soon as possible to discuss any proposed actions on case. You will be notiﬁed when the case is completed and Competent Authority
The CP analyst will copy the USCA analyst’s e

mail message and paste it into the ICS history. It will be the obligation of the USCA analyst to notify the CP analyst when the case is closed. The CP analyst will make a note about the closure in the ICS history.

) Consult your manager if you believe that suspension of collection activity adversely impact the government’s interest. Your manager may contact the USCA analyst to discuss the case and resolve any conﬂict. (
) Qualiﬁed intermediary (QI) cases involve foreign entities that enter into a qualiﬁed intermediary agreement with the IRS. Rev. Proc.
QI agreements. (
) QIs ﬁle Form
, Annual Withholding Tax Return for U.S. Source Income Foreign Persons. (
) QIs are assigned a special QI Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) ranging from
XXXX to
XXXX. (
) Check IDRS command code AMDISA when there is a -L freeze on the indicating open examination activity. If the case is assigned to a revenue Working agent, contact that agent before proceeding. (
) Determine if the liability is correct and not the result of an error by the QI or IRS. QIs can claim the withholding credits even though they are not primary withholding responsibility. (
) Check Form
, line

to verify that the QI claimed the proper credits. Also, verify the credits in IRS systems by checking IDRS command code IRPTRL and the Entellitrak (E-TRAK) system. The Accounts System (AMS) may also contain some of the information you need. (

) When ROs request the E-TRAK information, they must put something in the ICS history indicating that they sent the request to the group’s E-TRAK resource person and include that person’s name. GM approval is not and there is no need for the E-TRAK resource person to access the case to verify completion of the request. (

) Use internal sources such as IDRS to locate a telephone contact number for the QI or contact the QI team for assistance. If telephone contact is not suc- cessful, in order to meet your initial contact time requirement, you may send an appointment letter for a telephone meeting and enclose Publication Rights as a Taxpayer. Note: The RO may also enclose Letter
, Notice of Intent to Levy and Notice Your Right to a Hearing, with the appointment letter. However, the RO not send L-
by itself on initial contact. (
) Take the appropriate action in the following situations: a. If the QI did not claim any credits, send L-
to the QI. b. If the QI claimed the credits correctly on Form
, line

, and the has veriﬁed on E-TRAK that the credits are there, but the credit was properly credited on IDRS, contact the QI Technical Advisor Team Manager. Note: Information to contact the QI manager and a list of QI Technical Advisors is located qualiﬁed-intermediary-system.
a. If the QI did not claim any credits, send L-
to the QI. b. If the QI claimed the credits correctly on Form
, line
, and the RO has veriﬁed on E-TRAK that the credits are there, but the credit was not properly credited on IDRS, contact the QI Technical Advisor Team Manager.
International and Insular c. If the QI mistakenly did not claim the credits, so there are no credits on line
of Form
, secure from the QI copies of Forms
-S,, For- eign Person’s U.S. Source Income Subject to Withholding, a letter from the QI explaining the reason for requesting an adjustment, and a cor- rected Form
You will need these documents to prepare an adjustment. See IRM
, Adjustments on Qualiﬁed Intermediary Cases. d. Revenue Officers may not report a QI case as Currently Not Collectible (CNC). (
) Contact the QI team prior to taking any further case action if no response is received from the QI. The QI team will send a letter to the QI requiring them contact the revenue officer. (
) Verify that the QI did not contact the QI team before pursuing collection (
) Continue with normal collection actions if the QI does not contact you within

days, such as ﬁling the notice of federal tax lien, issuing levies, etc. Note: Do not assess the trust fund recovery penalty against the Qualiﬁed diaries since the QI agreement contains provisions that penalize the QI for nonpayment of withholding taxes. (

) The United States has six bilateral tax treaties that contain broad provisions mutual assistance in collection. Note: Many U.S. tax treaties contain separate collection assistance provisions intended to prevent improper use of the treaties. These limited collection sistance provisions focus on exemptions or reduced rates of tax granted under the treaty. (

) MCAR is used to combat international tax avoidance and evasion by a procedure for collecting taxes on behalf of a treaty partner. MCAR create a mutual obligation for each contracting country to use its domestic lection procedures to collect the taxes of a treaty partner upon request. (

) There are currently six bilateral income tax treaties that provide for MCAR. These treaties are with the following countries and cover the following taxes: • Canada – All taxes including both individual and business • Denmark – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes • France – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes • Japan - Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes • The Netherlands – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes • Sweden – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes (

) The MCAR program is administered by the USCA, which is part of LB&I, with assistance provided by Small Business & Self Employed (SB/SE) Field tion Area Operations. a. The USCA is the coordinating authority with the foreign government. All inbound MCARs are received and processed through the USCA . All communications with a treaty partner must be transmitted through the USCA.. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

You will need these documents to prepare an adjustment. See IRM
, Adjustments on Qualiﬁed Intermediary Cases. d. Revenue Officers may not report a QI case as Currently Not (CNC). (

Note: Do not assess the trust fund recovery penalty against the Qualiﬁed Interme- diaries since the QI agreement contains provisions that penalize the QI for nonpayment of withholding taxes.

The United States has six bilateral tax treaties that contain broad mutual assistance in collection. Many U.S. tax treaties contain separate collection assistance intended to prevent improper use of the treaties. These limited sistance provisions focus on exemptions or reduced rates of tax under the treaty. MCAR is used to combat international tax avoidance and evasion by a procedure for collecting taxes on behalf of a treaty partner. MCAR create a mutual obligation for each contracting country to use its lection procedures to collect the taxes of a treaty partner upon request. There are currently six bilateral income tax treaties that provide for These treaties are with the following countries and cover the following
Canada – All taxes including both individual and business
Denmark – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes
France – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes
Japan
Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes
The Netherlands – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes

Sweden – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes The MCAR program is administered by the USCA, which is part of LB&I, assistance provided by Small Business & Self Employed (SB/SE) Field tion Area Operations. a. The USCA is the coordinating authority with the foreign inbound MCARs are received and processed through the USCA . communications with a treaty partner must be transmitted through USCA..
(06-03-2020) Mutual Collection Assistance Requests (MCAR)

Note: Many U.S. tax treaties contain separate collection assistance provisions intended to prevent improper use of the treaties. These limited collection sistance provisions focus on exemptions or reduced rates of tax granted under the treaty.
There are currently six bilateral income tax treaties that provide for MCAR. These treaties are with the following countries and cover the following taxes:
Canada – All taxes including both individual and business Denmark – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes France – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes Japan
Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes The Netherlands – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes Sweden – Income taxes and other speciﬁed taxes

The USCA is the coordinating authority with the foreign government. All inbound MCARs are received and processed through the USCA . All communications with a treaty partner must be transmitted through the USCA..
Note: The name of the MCAR coordinators is available at:http://mysbse.web.irs. gov/Collection/international/mcar/contacts/20805.aspx
) Each of the countries listed in IRM

) may request assistance from the United States in collecting taxes owed to it. Such requests are called “Inbound MCARs.” All inbound MCARs are sent to the USCA who is the only IRS official authorized to receive such request. When approved, the USCA will forward such inbound MCARs to SBSE for collection action. The Service will not pursue collection on behalf of the treaty partner if the indi- vidual subject to collection is a citizen of the United States.
(06-03-2020) Inbound Mutual Collection Assistance Request
The Service will not pursue collection on behalf of the treaty partner if the vidual subject to collection is a citizen of the United States.
For MCAR cases received from Canada and Denmark, this limitation applies to inbound MCARs relating to taxable periods during which the individual was a U.S. citizen.

Exception: For cases received from Japan, this citizenship limitation does not apply to individuals who ﬁled a fraudulent tax return or a fraudulent claim for refund, willfully failed to ﬁle to evade taxes, or transferred assets to U.S. to avoid collection.

MCARs are sent by the treaty country to USCA. Only the USCA is authorized to receive such requests. MCARs come in the form of a written request. All MCARs must include a statement to the effect that the tax has been “ﬁnally determined,” as required by each treaty. The USCA forwards inbound MCARs to SBSE for collection action.

a. Name b. Address c. Type of tax and tax period(s) d. Amount(s) due in the currency of the treaty partner e. Date of Foreign Collection Deadline (FCD) Note: The FCD for each MCAR is provided by the treaty partner. statute date is shown on the Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcates. action is required by the Service to protect MCAR collection statutes.

Note: If the FCD is set to pass within
months, the MCAR coordinator should request an updated FCD from the USCA. If the FCD has not been updated within

days after the request, the MCAR dinator should follow-up with the USCA. If the FCD has passed, keep the case open and follow-up with the USCA to determine whether the treaty partner has extended the FCD prior to the expi- ration date. f. Any known levy sources or assets located within the United States (

) All inbound MCAR case referrals are maintained on the MCAR Database. The MCAR coordinator will add the inbound MCAR case referrals to the MCAR Database. The MCAR Database is used to track inventory, prepare the Tax Liability Certiﬁcate, prepare notices, letters, and post payments. • A case is also created on ICS as a Compliance Initiative Program (CIP) . ICS will be utilized to track inventory, maintain case histories, and charge time for the inbound MCAR cases. The grade of the inbound MCAR case will be determined based on the complexity of the case, using the same grading criteria as in domestic cases. See IRM Caution: MCAR cases are foreign assessments, and therefore the as- sessment will not show on IDRS. Do not add assessments to IDRS. The MCAR coordinator will prepare a Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate to record the liability.
If the FCD is set to pass within
months, the MCAR coordinator should request an updated FCD from the USCA. If the FCD has not been updated within

days after the request, the MCAR coor- dinator should follow-up with the USCA. If the FCD has passed, keep the case open and follow-up with the USCA to determine whether the treaty partner has extended the FCD prior to the expi- ration date.

All inbound MCAR case referrals are maintained on the MCAR Database. The MCAR coordinator will add the inbound MCAR case referrals to the MCAR Database. The MCAR Database is used to track inventory, prepare the Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate, prepare notices, letters, and post payments.

A case is also created on ICS as a Compliance Initiative Program (CIP) . ICS will be utilized to track inventory, maintain case histories, and charge time for the inbound MCAR cases. The grade of the inbound MCAR case will be determined based on the complexity of the case, using the same grading criteria as in domestic cases. See IRM
) The MCAR coordinator will update the ICS case code/sub code accordingly. (

) Conduct research using IDRS, Accurint and other locator sources to locate following information: • A U.S. Social Security number or Tax Identiﬁcation number • Taxpayer’s citizenship • Taxpayer’s address and/or contact information • The latest return ﬁled • Possible levy sources • Any open U.S. tax liability Note: Priority should always be given to collecting taxes owed to the United by the taxpayer before collecting the foreign taxes owed. (

) Since the Internal Revenue Code requires an assessment before the Service can take any enforcement action, the Service must prepare a Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate. The foreign tax liability is shown in U.S. dollars (USD) on Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate. Note: IRC

(a) authorizes the Service to make assessments of taxes imposed by the IRC. The bilateral treaties become part of US law and may be imple- mented through the IRC’s assessment and collection procedures for domestic taxes.
Conduct research using IDRS, Accurint and other locator sources to locate following information:
A U.S. Social Security number or Tax Identiﬁcation number
Taxpayer’s citizenship
Taxpayer’s address and/or contact information
The latest return ﬁled
Possible levy sources
Any open U.S. tax liability
Note: Priority should always be given to collecting taxes owed to the United States by the taxpayer before collecting the foreign taxes owed.

) Since the Internal Revenue Code requires an assessment before the Service can take any enforcement action, the Service must prepare a Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate. The foreign tax liability is shown in U.S. dollars (USD) on a Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate.
A Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate is prepared by the MCAR coordinator utilizing the MCAR Database and includes the following:

a. If the foreign tax liability is listed in U.S. dollars, use that ﬁgure for the Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate, otherwise convert the tax liability into U.S. dollars using the exchange rate on the date the Foreign Tax Certiﬁcate is prepared. b. A Taxpayer Control Number (TCN) is created automatically when the case is added to the MCAR database. The format for the TCN is

- MCA-NNNNN. If this taxpayer also has an SSN, the SSN should also appear on the Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate. Note: An inbound MCAR case has three different control numbers, case number assigned by the treaty partner, another case assigned by USCA, and the TCN. The TCN is used by The treaty partner and USCA do not use the TCN. c. The Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate is signed and dated by the MCAR coordinator. Note: The date the MCAR was received by USCA is treated as the of assessment for all enforcement actions taken by the Service the United States, including for purposes of completing a Notice Federal Tax Lien.

Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate, otherwise convert the tax liability into U.S. dollars using the exchange rate on the date the Foreign Tax Certiﬁcate is prepared. A Taxpayer Control Number (TCN) is created automatically when the case is added to the MCAR database. The format for the TCN is
- MCA-NNNNN. If this taxpayer also has an SSN, the SSN should also appear on the Foreign Tax Liability Certiﬁcate.

, Collection Appeal Rights A taxpayer identiﬁed in an inbound MCAR case is not entitled to a tion Due Process (CDP) hearing because the tax liability at issue is a foreign tax liability. , Collection Appeal Rights A taxpayer identiﬁed in an inbound MCAR case is not entitled to a Collec- tion Due Process (CDP) hearing because the tax liability at issue is a foreign tax liability. A taxpayer may request review under the Collection
International and Insular Issues

to adjust a foreign tax liability, but it does have the authority, for to advise the MCAR coordinator to withdraw the Notice of Federal Tax Lien if Appeals determines that one of the conditions in section
(j) exists. See IRM
, Collection Appeals Program.. c. For taxpayers requesting a CDP hearing, Letter

should be sent to the taxpayer denying their request for a CDP hearing. Taxpayers can request a CAP in connection with the ﬁling of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien or a Notice of Intent to Levy. The response from the taxpayer will determine the next action to take in an MCAR case. a. Full pay The taxpayer has the option to make payments by check or money made payable to the treaty partner in either the currency of the treaty partner or in U.S. dollars. Payment in the currency of the treaty partner preferred. The MCAR coordinator will forward the payment directly to treaty partner. b. Short Term Payment Plan • Secure a complete Form
-A, Collection Information Statement and verify all ﬁnancial information in accordance with IRM
, Financial Analysis, if the taxpayer cannot full pay the MCAR liability. • Complete Letter
, MCAR - Short Term Payment Plan, and mail the taxpayer. Letter

provides the taxpayer with instructions on to make the payments, where to send the payments and who to if the taxpayer has questions. • All short term payment plans are approved and manually monitored the MCAR coordinator for a period of
days. After the taxpayer has complied with the short term payment plan for

days, instruct the taxpayer to make further payments directly to the treaty partner. c. Disputed Tax Liability • Taxpayer cannot dispute the MCAR tax liability with the IRS.. Direct taxpayer to raise any dispute regarding the liability to with the treaty partner. The United States has no statutory authority to adjust a foreign tax liability. Note: Unless the treaty partner contacts USCA to cease collection the MCAR coordinator should continue with collection action. If dispute is still unresolved after

days, the MCAR coordinator should request an update from USCA to determine resolution of collection matter with the treaty partner. d. United States Citizenship • U.S. citizenship limits MCAR collections. The Service cannot collect liabilities owed to France, the Netherlands or Sweden from individuals who are U.S. citizens. If the taxpayer provides proof of U.S. close the collection case and contact the MCAR coordinator. * The Service cannot collect tax liabilities owed to Canada or Denmark from individuals who were U.S. citizens during the tax period at issue. the taxpayer provides proof of U.S. citizenship during the tax period at issue, close the collection case and contact the MCAR coordinator. * The Service cannot collect tax liabilities owed to Japan from who are U.S. citizens unless the taxpayer ﬁled a fraudulent return or refund claim, willfully failed to ﬁle a return to evade tax or transferred
to advise the MCAR coordinator to withdraw the Notice of Federal Tax Lien if Appeals determines that one of the conditions in section
(j) exists. See IRM
, Collection Appeals Program.. c. For taxpayers requesting a CDP hearing, Letter
should be sent to the taxpayer denying their request for a CDP hearing. Taxpayers can request a CAP in connection with the ﬁling of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien or a Notice of Intent to Levy.

a. Full pay The taxpayer has the option to make payments by check or money made payable to the treaty partner in either the currency of the treaty partner or in U.S. dollars. Payment in the currency of the treaty partner preferred. The MCAR coordinator will forward the payment directly to treaty partner. b. Short Term Payment Plan • Secure a complete Form
-A, Collection Information Statement and verify all ﬁnancial information in accordance with IRM
, Financial Analysis, if the taxpayer cannot full pay the MCAR liability. • Complete Letter
, MCAR - Short Term Payment Plan, and mail to the taxpayer. Letter

provides the taxpayer with instructions on how to make the payments, where to send the payments and who to contact if the taxpayer has questions. • All short term payment plans are approved and manually monitored by the MCAR coordinator for a period of
days. After the taxpayer has complied with the short term payment plan for

days, instruct the taxpayer to make further payments directly to the treaty partner. c. Disputed Tax Liability • Taxpayer cannot dispute the MCAR tax liability with the IRS.. Direct taxpayer to raise any dispute regarding the liability to with the treaty partner. The United States has no statutory authority to adjust a foreign tax liability. Note: Unless the treaty partner contacts USCA to cease collection
Note: Unless the treaty partner contacts USCA to cease collection action, the MCAR coordinator should continue with collection action. If the dispute is still unresolved after

days, the MCAR coordinator should request an update from USCA to determine resolution of the collection matter with the treaty partner. United States Citizenship • U.S. citizenship limits MCAR collections. The Service cannot collect tax liabilities owed to France, the Netherlands or Sweden from individuals who are U.S. citizens. If the taxpayer provides proof of U.S. citizenship, close the collection case and contact the MCAR coordinator. * The Service cannot collect tax liabilities owed to Canada or Denmark from individuals who were U.S. citizens during the tax period at issue. e. Secure evidence of U.S citizenship. IF THEN The taxpayer is a U.S. Citizen by Secure a copy of taxpayer’s birth birth certiﬁcate or U.S. passport. The taxpayer is a naturalized Secure the number, date and U.S. Citizen place of issuance of the taxpay- er’s Certiﬁcate of Naturalization or a copy of U.S. passport. f. Unable to Pay/Unable to locate (UTL)/Currently Not Collectible (CNC) •If the taxpayer does not have the ability to full pay or set up a short payment plan on the foreign tax liability, the MCAR coordinator should close the case as unable to pay. The taxpayer should have completed a Form
-A, Collection Information Statement for Wage Earners and Employed Individuals, to show an inability to pay. See IRM
, Hardship, and IRM

, Financial Analysis Handbook, for procedures to make a hardship determination. If the taxpayer cannot be located, follow the same procedures as working a domestic case for a UTL CNC. Advise the MCAR coordinator that the taxpayer cannot be located in the United States. The MCAR coordinator will inform the USCA that the taxpayer cannot be located so the USCA can inform the treaty partner. g. Bankruptcy/Deceased Taxpayer • The taxpayer may ﬁle for bankruptcy. The Service can submit a proof claim to the appropriate U.S. court on behalf of the treaty partner and advise the treaty partner of developments in the proceedings through USCA. • A decedent estate or insolvency proceeding will be handled in a similar manner in state court. h. Offer in Compromise • The Service does not have the statutory authority to accept an offer to compromise for a foreign tax liability. Therefore, an offer in compromise not an option for the taxpayer to settle the liability. The MCAR coordina- tor must direct the taxpayer to the treaty partner for resolution of the account if Full Pay, Short Term Payment Plan, or CNC Hardship are not appropriate.

to close the case back to the treaty partner. The letter should contain an expla- nation regarding the disposition of the case. The MCAR Coordinator will route the closed MCAR case ﬁle to the Centralized Case Processing (CCP) Unit for storage according to record retention proce- dures. CCP will hold the closed MCAR case ﬁle for
days. After
days, CCP will send the closed MCAR case ﬁle to the Federal Records Center for a three-year retention period before the ﬁle is destroyed. (See Document
, IRS Records Control Schedules, RCS
for Tax Administration - Collection.)

) All checks or money orders submitted voluntarily by taxpayers may be in USD or the foreign currency of the particular treaty partner, but the foreign Payments currency is preferred. If payment is in U.S. dollars, the liability is fully paid MCAR when the total payments match the dollar amount on the Foreign Tax Certiﬁcate. If the payment is in the foreign currency, the tax liability is fully when total payments match the tax liability stated by the treaty partner in its currency in the MCAR letter. (
) The check or money order should be made payable to the treaty partner than the Service. (
) Do not accept payment in cash because Form
Receipt For Payment Taxes, cannot be issued for MCAR liabilities. (
) If taxpayer requests a receipt of payment, provide the taxpayer with a date- stamped photocopy of the check or money order. (
) After the Letter

, Final Notice, Notice of Intent to Levy is sent to the taxpayer, and there is no response, or an insufficient response from the Action on taxpayer, the MCAR coordinator will, if possible, utilize internal and external locator sources to ﬁnd levy sources and/or locate taxpayers. (

) In situations where the notices are undelivered, the MCAR coordinator will issue a courtesy investigation to the appropriate Field Collection Area to a ﬁeld visit to taxpayer’s last known address. (

) Take the same enforcement actions as would be appropriate for a domestic Bal Due taxpayer, although the processing for certain distraint actions will slightly from that for domestic Bal Dues. See IRM

) If enforcement action is not taken on any assets, document why action was not taken against each identiﬁed asset. This documentation will assure the USCA that all possible efforts were made to collect the foreign liability. (

) Prior to preparing any levy for amounts due pursuant to an MCAR, check IDRS for any deﬁciencies owed by the taxpayer. If the taxpayer has MCAR cies for U.S. tax, include these amounts in the levy. (
) If the taxpayer does not have a U.S. tax liability currently owing, proceed the levy. Prepare all notice of levy forms and follow the guidelines under

If the taxpayer has deﬁciencies for U.S. tax and there is no domestic revenue officer assigned to collect the U.S. tax liability, contact your manager regarding further action. If a domestic revenue officer is assigned to collect the U.S. tax liability, coordinate collection with that officer using the following procedures:
The domestic and MCAR revenue officers must coordinate closely issuing notices of levy. Prepare one notice of levy per collection See IRM

, Notice of Levy. The notice of levy should list both U.S. liability and the MCAR revenue claims. The domestic revenue officer is in charge of the levy. Accordingly, the notice of levy is prepared and served by the domestic revenue officer, and the domestic revenue officer should manage the levy. The revenue officer will coordinate with the MCAR revenue officer and updates. In general, the collection of U.S. tax liabilities takes priority over on behalf of a treaty partner. Amounts collected pursuant to a levy be applied ﬁrst to the U.S. tax liability. Once the U.S. tax liability is fully paid, amounts collected will be applied to the MCAR claim.
5.21 International and Insular Issues

Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) ﬁling determination should be made using the same criteria as if the tax liability were a U.S. tax liability. Do not utilize the Automated Lien System (ALS) to ﬁle NFTLs for liabilities. See IRM

, Preparation of MCAR NFTLs, for the procedures for ﬁling NFTL notice on MCARs. File an NFTL prior to a seizure ofany of the taxpayer’s assets, real or personal. File an NFTL if the taxpayer has the ability to pay, but refuses to do and the taxpayer owns real property to which the NFTL will attach. File an NFTL if the MCAR case is currently not collectible and the taxpayer owns real property to which the NFTL will attach. Although Field Collection Areas may ﬁle NFTLs for MCARs, The MCAR ordinator will be responsible for the release of these liens after the

Do not generate a Collection Due Process (CDP) notice for an MCAR NFTL notice. A taxpayer identiﬁed in an inbound MCAR case is not entitled to a Collection Due Process (CDP) hearing because the tax liability at issue is a foreign tax liability. A taxpayer may request review under the Collection Appeals Program (CAP). See IRM
, Collection Appeals Program. The taxpayer should be directed to raise any disputes about liability, the Foreign Collection Deadline, or payments directly to the treaty partner.
(06-03-2020) Seizure and Sale on MCARs
a seizure and sale will ﬁrst be applied to US deﬁciencies, with any remaining funds applied to the MCAR. Procedures for the seizure and sale of personal and real property are found in IRM
, Mutual Collection Assistance Requests. Generally, IRM

, Seizure and Sale, provisions apply to MCAR collection matters with the following exceptions: a. Prior to taking seizure action: • Contact both the Property Appraisal and Liquidation Specialist (PALS) and MCAR coordinator. • Discuss the facts of the case, including the actions taken prior to the proposed seizure, the type and value of the property to be seized, and the expected revenue. b. If the MCAR coordinator concurs with the proposed seizure: • Submit the case for approval through your group manager (according to the current IRM provisions for managerial review). • Coordinate the seizure with MCAR coordinator and with the PALS. The PALS will also coordinate the sale with the MCAR coordinator. • Contact the OI originator if any questions or problems arise. c. Preparing Form
-B, Levy: • Contact the MCAR coordinator to secure a sample of Form

-B to assist in your seizure and sale preparation. All seizure and sale forms that are prepared must refer to the MCAR liability in a similar manner and contain no reference to U.S. taxes. • Do not bid on or purchase seized property on behalf of the U.S. govern- ment or its treaty partners in the event that the minimum bid is not received. If appropriate, the sale may be adjourned and rescheduled
a seizure and sale will ﬁrst be applied to US deﬁciencies, with any remaining funds applied to the MCAR. Procedures for the seizure and sale of personal and real property are found in IRM
, Mutual Collection Assistance Requests. Generally, IRM
, Seizure and Sale, provisions apply to MCAR collection matters with the following exceptions:
within the allowable one-month time period under IRC

for seizure and sale expenses because expenses of seizures and sales will not be assessed against MCAR taxpayers. In addition, the foreign tax liability will not be on IDRS. • Forward monies collected immediately to the SB/SE MCAR coordinator.

If the taxpayer has deﬁciencies for U.S. tax and there is no domestic revenue officer assigned to collect the U.S. tax liability, contact your manager regarding further action. If a domestic revenue officer is assigned to collect the U.S. tax liability, coordinate collection with revenue officer using the following procedures: a. The domestic and MCAR revenue officers must coordinate closely issuing seizure documents . Prepare one set of seizure documents per collection source. See IRM

, Seizure and Sale. The seizure documents should list both the U.S. tax liabilities and MCAR revenue claims.. b. The domestic revenue officer is in charge of the seizure. Accordingly, seizure documents are prepared and served by the domestic revenue officer, and the domestic revenue officer should carry out the seizure. The domestic revenue officer will coordinate with the MCAR revenue officer and provide updates. c. The PALS assigned to sell the seized assets should provide updates to both the domestic revenue officer and the MCAR revenue officer. d. In general, the collection of U.S. tax liabilities takes priority over on behalf of a treaty partner. Where the seizure documents list both the U.S. domestic liability and the MCAR claim, amounts should be applied ﬁrst to costs of sale, then to the U.S. domestic liability, and then to the MCAR claim. e. In the event that the MCAR revenue claim is not listed on the seizure documents, and the sale of the seized asset results in surplus the MCAR revenue officer should seek to have the surplus proceeds applied to the MCAR revenue claim. See IRM
, Disposing of Surplus Proceeds. The treaties listed in IRM

5.21 International and Insular Issues

These treaties provide that each country, upon request by the United States, may take whatever actions it would take to collect its own taxes in order to collect on behalf of the United States. This includes the collection of U.S. taxes through the treaty partner’s bankruptcy proceedings.

The treaty with Canada, and the treaty with Denmark provide that they will collect from taxpayers who were not their citizens during the tax periods which the U.S. tax liability relates, even if they subsequently became citizens. The treaties for France, The Netherlands, Japan and Sweden provide that those countries will not collect from their own citizens. The treaty with Japan has certain exceptions to this citizenship limitation for fraud and evasion. Coordinate any proposed MCAR to Japan with Associate Chief Counsel, International, Branch
Caution: The treaty with Japan provides that Japan will collect from taxpayers are not “Nationals”. Coordinate any proposed MCAR to Japan with Chief Counsel, International, Branch

) Once the international or domestic revenue officer has reason to believe there are collectable assets in a treaty partner country, the revenue officer can prepare an outbound MCAR for approval. Note: The revenue officer may issue an OI to international ﬁeld collection to income or assets in the treaty partner country prior to referring the case for an outbound MCAR. (
) All outbound MCARs require coordination with the MCAR coordinator. (
) The MCAR coordinators are listed on the Mutual Collection Assistance Requests (MCAR) web page. The direct link to the page is: irs.gov/Collection/international/mcar/contacts/
aspx.

All outbound MCAR case referrals are maintained on the MCAR Database. The MCAR coordinator will add the outbound MCAR case referrals to the
MCAR Database. The MCAR Database is used to track inventory, charge time, prepare the Assessment Certiﬁcate, prepare notices and letters and post payments.
Before requesting an outbound MCAR, make sure a Letter 1058 or LT 11 has been issued to the taxpayer for each tax and period listed on the MCAR.
Compute the accruals to 180 days from the date of the referral.

The following case closures meet the requirements to withdraw the MCAR referral: • Taxpayer has full paid the total liability. • Taxpayer has entered into an installment plan. • Taxpayer has accepted an offer in compromise. • Taxpayer is currently not collectible due to a hardship. • The CSED has passed.. • An adjustment is pending or has posted that will result in a zero balance.

An RO in International has a Bal Due case totaling $77,000. The Bal Dues are a result of returns ﬁled by the taxpayer, who is a U.S. citizens. The International revenue officer contacted taxpayer in Canada conﬁrm- ing that taxpayer is residing in Canada. The revenue officer completed Form 14424 and the case was accepted by the MCAR coordinator as a outbound MCAR referral to Canada. Canadian Revenue contacted taxpayer but taxpayer chose to work with the International RO to pay U.S. tax liability directly to the IRS. TP entered into an approved short term payment plan. The outbound MCAR referral is then withdrawn by the RO using the procedures in IRM 5.21.7.4.10.1.
